media.title:
Itâs been a looong time since Iâve posted, and Iâve never actually introduced myself (mainly because I hate introducing myself), so I felt it was time to try it.

So hi, my name is Betinna. Iâm from Denmark and work as a librarian at an architecture school. I am also married to a librarian, which is extra convenient in these times where we work from home most of the time. Automatic work-from-home-buddy.
.
I mainly draw with ballpoint pen, often combined with either acrylic paint or watercolour, and nature and fantasy are my main sources of inspiration.
.
Iâd love to hear a bit about you too, so feel free to say hi in the comments. ð
.

title:
When deciding on the composition of the birds for this drawing, I first sketched them in as very rudimentary shapes showing placement and direction (second photo). Then I took a good look through the stock photos I mentioned in my last post to figure out what fit where. 
.
After much sketching and erasing and re-sketching, I had figured out most of the birds, but the last two were giving me trouble, so I sketched a couple of possibilities out on transparent paper (third and fourth photo). That way I could moved them around and flip them over to see how they would fit.
.
In the original sketch I had some of the birds flying away from the face, but during this process I decided against that because it confused the focus of the drawing and lead the eye towards the edge of the paper.
.
#slowtober2020 #slowtober #artprocess #artproject #ballpointpen #ballpointpenart #ballpointpenartwork #ballpointpendrawings #ballpointpens #birdart #birdartwork #birddrawing #birddrawings #danishart #danishartist #disegni #dessin #sparrow  #nordicart #nordicartist #portraitdrawing #portraitdrawings #sparrows #teckning #teckningar #tegning #tegninger #traditionalartwork #traditionaldrawing #traditionaldrawings

Besides flowers, I always like to include birds in my portrait drawings. Usually just a single one sitting on the person. When Iâve drawn flying birds before it has always been small scale and mostly just one at a time. So since the aim here was bigger and more detailed, I decided that what this drawing needed was a whole flock of sparrows, as they have lovely detailed feathers (and are really cute).
.
So I downloaded all the stock photos of flying sparrows I could find on @pixabay and started figuring out which birds fitted where. 
.
Iâve included the stock photos I ended up using. Swipe to see them in order from the top left of the drawing and counter-clockwise. The two last ones are outside this section of the drawing, but youâll see them later on.
.
All @pixabay photos are under a free license that allows commercial and noncommercial use across print and digital, except in some specific cases, and attribution is not required. Which is why it is usually my first stop if I need references that I cannot make myself.
.

.
What I am making for this challenge is a piece that is both larger and more detailed than my usual work. And while it probably seems like Iâm getting a bit of a late start, I have actually been working on it all month (and a tiny bit before), so this is just the first of a number of progress shots I have ready. I have gotten back into sketching and drawing quick things (such as this) in the evenings and afternoons while watching tv these past weeks. A nice way to feel a little productive while still being a couch potato.
.
My back is doing better than last year. Iâm going to the gym twice a week, and I havenât been to see my physiotherapist since before Christmas, but I still have to be careful, and I canât draw at my desk for long, before my back starts acting up. So I spend a lot of time on the couch, propped up by pillows to relieve it. But it is progress.
.

media.title:
Hands! I never thought, Iâd get to a point where I would enjoy drawing them. But I do now. A few @skillshare courses (I can recommend the ones by Arleesha Yetzer / @arleebean ) and lots of focus on practicing has definitely helped me to get there. I still need to practice, practice, practice, but I no longer feel the need to strategically omit the hands in all my drawings. Which in turn leads to more practice. An all-round win. ð
.
Do you have something you avoid drawing as much as possible? I used to do it with ears as well. It feels like Iâve been learning to draw one body part at a time. ð
.

Happy new year everyone! I hope you had a safe passage into the new year.
.
There's this event going on called #januart where you draw something everyday in January based on a daily prompt (swipe to see list). If it sounds familiar it is because it is like a German version of Inktober.
.
I thought it could be fun to participate now that I didn't have the chance to participate in #inktober2018 and I even made this drawing based on the first prompt, Feuerwerk. But since @wirmoechtengernkunst made this event for German speaking artists, and I'm not actually a German speaker, even though I speak German as a third language, it feels weird to butt in. And besides I'm no good at sticking to prompt lists. ð
.
So instead I'll just use this opportunity to advertise this event to any German speakers who see this that don't already know it. It's not to late to check it out. ð
.
Frohes neues Jahr!
.

title:
A #drawthisinyourstyle for #pernillesholidaychallenge ð¸ð¿ð¸ð¿
.
Itâs been a while since Iâve posted, but I return with good news! ð
.
After a little more than five months, we finally found out what was causing the pain in my hands. And itâs been fixed. More or less. It turned out that one or more of the small bones in both my wrists were out of place. They were pushing on all kinds of things that they shouldnât, which explains both the pain that got worse whenever I used my hands as well as the random numbness. After a couple of months of weekly physiotherapy treatments my physiotherapist was able to yank things back in place.
.
I still have to be careful not to overexert my hands or lift too much/lift in the wrong way, and sometimes I can feel the bones getting out of place again, but now that I know what is wrong, I can sort of shake things back.
.
To be honest, this whole thing has been extremely stressful. A lot of the time I found it difficult to believe I would ever get the full use of my hands back. Especially the last weeks where it stoped getting better despite the treatments and the care I took not to use my hands. So itâs been such a relief to find out what was wrong and to be able to do stupid everyday stuff again. I never thought Iâd be so grateful for being able to wash the dishes or cut bread, and Iâm so happy to be able to draw again. ð­
.
Thank you for reading, if you made it this far! ð
.

title:
Watercolour experiment I did during my summer holiday.

I tried not stretching the paper before I started, but it didnât take long before it buckled too much for it to be practical to work on. Since I wasnât too happy with the way the colours looked anyway, I put it in water to soak, and flattened it on a glass surface. This made it much easier to work on, even after it dried and became a little curved.
.
After I was all done with it, I wet the back of the painting a bit and pressed it flat, in the hope that when it dried it would turn out completely flat. It didnât quite work, but Iâm thinking that maybe I didnât leave it under pressure long enough. So Iâll try it again in the future, to see if I can get it to work.
.

My first go at stretching watercolour paper was somewhat successful (after three tries). It didnât end up completely flat, but the warping is minimal, which is a great improvement.
.
The water activated tape was nice to work with, after I figured out how much water to use with it. Too little and it is to dry to stick, too much and the gum is washed off, and it still doesnât stick.
.
I do however definitely need a better surface for stretching the paper on. I first tried using a MDF board, but I got it wet when removing the tape after the first try resulting in warping along two edges (not enough water on the tape). So the second attempt wasnât successful because the board curved as it dried. For the third attempt I used (please donât laugh) a hardcover scrapbook that was still wrapped in plastic. It worked okay, but the plastic was stretchy enough for the tape to buckle a bit. So now Iâm looking for something better. Any suggestions?
.
